noun.description: The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.
examples: he lay on his back
back pain
Forbes slapped me on the back

noun.description: The side or part of something that is away from the spectator or from the direction in which it moves or faces; the rear.
examples: at the back of the hotel is a secluded garden
an empty spot in the back of the plane

noun.description: A player in a field game whose initial position is behind the front line.
examples: their backs showed some impressive running and passing

adverb.description: Toward the rear; in the opposite direction from the one that one is facing or traveling.
examples: she moved back a pace
she walked away without looking back

adverb.description: Expressing a return to an earlier or normal condition.
examples: she put the book back on the shelf
drive to Montreal and back
I went back to sleep
he was given his job back
he made his fortune back in 1955
they wrote back to me

verb.description: Give financial, material, or moral support to.
examples: he had a newspaper empire backing him
go up there and tell them—I'll back you up

verb.description: Cover the back of (an object) in order to support, protect, or decorate it.
examples: a mirror backed with tortoiseshell
she tried to back away
the administration backed away from the plan
he backed the Mercedes into the yard
backing down the stairs

verb.description: (of a property) have its back adjacent to (a piece of land or body of water)
examples: his garage wall backs onto the neighboring property
a row of cottages backed on the water

adjective.description: Of or at the back of something.
examples: the back garden
the back pocket of his jeans

adjective.description: (especially of wages or something published or released) from or relating to the past.
examples: she was owed back pay

adjective.description: Directed toward the rear or in a reversed course.
examples: back currents

adjective.description: (of a sound) articulated at the back of the mouth.

phrases: I've got the will of the people at my back, he said at the moment of victory.
I just jumped down into this crevice, behind this big boulder and then there's a god almighty bang as the forth RPG comes in at my back.
Now that I've got the will of the people at my back, I'm going to start enforcing the one-question rule.
You get the ball and you give it straight away as you have a man at your back.
The country is secure, no longer having its neighbor's tank armies and radical nationalist influence at its back.
the contenders backed down from their original pledge
He is not from a family that backs down, even if it means risking one's life.
However, neither the French nor Austrian governments showed any sign of backing down from their proposals.
Burton, he added affectionately, never backs down, whether the fight is within his own party or outside it.
She makes her opinion known, never backs down and never lets up.
origin: Old English bæc, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Dutch and Old Norse bak. The adverb use dates from late Middle English and is a shortening of aback.
